snippet: A plunge in relations between the United States and Pakistan has led to a pause in American drone strikes and given Al Qaeda and Pakistani factions a chance to regroup.
abstract: Nearly two-month lull in American drone strikes in Pakistan has helped embolden Al Qaeda and several Pakistani militant factions to regroup, increase attacks against Pakistani security forces and threaten intensified strikes against allied forces in Afghanistan; diplomats and intelligence analysts say the pause in missile strikes is offering greater freedom of movement to an insurgency that had been battered by American drone attacks.

byline.contributor: Pir Zubair Shah contributed reporting from Cambridge, Mass., and Ismail Khan from Peshawar, Pakistan.

lead_paragraph: A plunge in relations between the United States and Pakistan has led to a pause in American drone strikes and given Al Qaeda and Pakistani factions a chance to regroup.

headline.seo: Lull in U.S. Drone Strikes Aids Pakistan Militants
headline.main: Lull in Strikes by U.S. Drones Aids Militants in Pakistan
headline.print_headline: Lull In Strikes By U.S. Drones Aids Militants

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
